content:
The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2008" limits the amount of grants and assistance provided under Section 14321(a) of title 40, United States Code. The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2008" set limits on administrative expenses for grants to local development districts based on their economic development focus and county designation status. The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2008" established limits on the cost-sharing requirements for projects eligible for financial assistance under the act. The limits vary based on the county's economic designation status, with different percentages of funding available from amounts appropriated to carry out the act. Amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 set limits on cost-sharing for health projects. Grants can cover up to 50-80% of project costs based on county economic designations. Amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 now allow for increased Commission contributions for projects in at-risk counties, with a maximum contribution of 70 percent. Additionally, assistance for low- and middle-income housing projects has been limited to cover costs related to planning and obtaining financing. The amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 allow for increased Commission contributions for projects in at-risk counties, with a maximum contribution of 70 percent for planning and obtaining financing costs. The amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 specify that grants for planning and financing expenses shall not exceed 50 percent for regular projects, 80 percent for distressed counties, and 70 percent for at-risk counties. Additionally, there is a limitation on available amounts for telecommunications and technology initiatives. Amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 set limitations on available amounts for telecommunications and technology initiatives. Grants for eligible activities cannot exceed 50 percent for regular projects, 80 percent for distressed counties, and 70 percent for at-risk counties. Amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 impose limitations on available amounts for grants under specific conditions. For regular projects, only 50 percent of the cost can be provided from appropriated funds, while distressed counties can receive up to 80 percent, and at-risk counties up to 70 percent. Amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 2008 set limits on grant funding based on county designations. Regular projects can receive up to 50% of the cost from appropriated funds, distressed counties up to 80%, and at-risk counties up to 70%. The Appalachian Regional Commission may increase the maximum contribution for projects in at-risk counties to 70 percent. Additionally, a new Economic and Energy Development Initiative allows for assistance in promoting energy efficiency, renewable energy resources, and regional development. The Appalachian Regional Commission aims to boost renewable energy use in the region for transportation fuels, electricity, and heat, while also supporting the development of conventional energy resources with advanced technologies to reduce emissions. Grants are limited to a maximum percentage of project costs based on county designations. The Appalachian Regional Commission allows grants to be provided from various sources, including other Federal programs, to support renewable energy projects. The Federal share can be increased as decided by the Commission. A conforming amendment is made to the analysis for chapter 145 of title 40, United States Code. SEC. 4. DISTRESSED, AT-RISK, AND ECONOMICALLY STRONG COUNTIES.
Designation of At-Risk Counties in the Appalachian region that are most at risk of becoming economically distressed. Authorization of appropriations for distressed, at-risk, and economically strong counties under the Appalachian Regional Commission is as follows: $87,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $108,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $110,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. Additionally, funds for the Economic and Energy Development Initiative are allocated as follows: $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $12,500,000 for fiscal year 2009, $13,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $13,500,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $14,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. Authorization of funds for the Appalachian Regional Commission for the years 2008 to 2012 is as follows: $12,000,000 for 2008, $12,500,000 for 2009, $13,000,000 for 2010, $13,500,000 for 2011, and $14,000,000 for 2012. Funds allocated for projects in the Appalachian region must come from the total amount allocated to each State by the Commission. Additionally, the termination date for section 14704 of title 40, United States Code, is changed from 2007 to 2012. Amendments are made to include new counties in Kentucky and Ohio. The code is amended to include new counties in various states: in Kentucky, Metcalfe is added after Menifee, Nicholas after Morgan, and Robertson after Pulaski; in Ohio, Ashtabula after Adams, Mahoning after Lawrence, and Trumbull after Scioto; in Tennessee, Lawrence and Lewis are added after Knox; and in Virginia, Henry after Grayson and Patrick after Montgomery.
